options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to give feedback on other seniors' projects
I learned a ton about why my classmates are involved in!
I learned about how to converse thoughtfully and ask questions about different cognitive science topics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Get to hear about the research fellow CogSci students are doing.
Weaknesses: online, it was always the same five people who talked every day. I wish more people were engaged b/c I didn't feel like I got that valuable of feedback, mostly I just knew I had to present so I did.
Great course needed for Cogsci major
Not particularly exciting but served its purpose

I enjoyed that it was casual and that students were allowed to just offer any thoughts, and get feedback on their thesis projects. I wish that there had been more engagement from everyone in the class, as it seems that only maybe half of the members were actively participating at any given time (further exacerbated by Zoom).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Joshua Knobe is, as always, a fantastic discussion facilitator and a brilliant professor. He was really great about synthesizing the feedback/questions everyone had for each other and asking interesting thought questions when people ran out of things to say. I do think it would have been fruitful to encourage all students to participate by turning their cameras on or incentivizing participation in some other way. Some students didn't say a word through the whole semester.

I appreciated that Josh would frequently solicit our questions and try to get input from those in the class. I also appreciated that the class was broken into two sections (such that each section had 20-some people). However, it's long nature also made the class sometimes hard to pay attention to on Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You have to take it lol
You have to take it as Cogsci but it is really a fun course!
Required for cognitive science majors, but yes it's fine

Though it is a requirement for Cognitive Science seniors, and thus not up to student's choice to take the course, it was somewhat helpful to get project feedback, especially early on. I will say that given the limited expertise of students (especially those not in the same field as me), they could only offer marginally helpful/feasible changes on my project. Perhaps it would have been cool to also meet with fellow cogsci seniors doing projects of similar topics as either part of class or in addition to what was done this past term.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
